conclusion: Two sufficiently long parallel metal rails are spaced at a distance of L=0.5m, with an inclination angle of θ=30° to the horizontal plane. They are placed in a uniform magnetic field with a magnetic induction strength of B=0.2T, directed vertically upward relative to the plane of the rails.
The conductor rods a and b on the rails have masses of ma=0.3kg and mb=0.1kg, respectively, and each has a resistance of R=0.1Ω.
The rods a and b are released from rest, and a constant force F of magnitude 2N is applied to rod a along the direction parallel to the rails, pulling it upward.
The rails are smooth, and their resistance is negligible. During the motion, the two rods remain perpendicular to the rails and maintain good contact.
The gravitational acceleration is taken as g=10m/s².
It is known that when the Joule heat generated in rod a is Qa=0.12J, its velocity is va=1.0m/s.
The problem asks for the speed magnitude of rod b.

The image shows two parallel metal rails inclined at an angle θ = 30° to the horizontal. Two conductor rods, a and b, are placed on these rails, perpendicular to them. A uniform magnetic field is directed vertically upwards. A force F = 2N is applied to rod a to pull it upward.
Calculate the net force acting on rod a: F_net = F - ma * g = 2N - 0.3kg * 10m/s² = 1.7N
Find the acceleration of rod a using Newton's second law: aa = F_net / ma = 1.7N / 0.3kg = 5.67m/s²
Determine the velocity of rod a when the Joule heat generated is Qa = 0.12J: va = sqrt(2Qa/ma) = sqrt(2 * 0.12J / 0.3kg) = 1.0m/s
Apply the principle of conservation of momentum: ma * va + mb * vb = 0. Solving for vb, we get: vb = -(ma/mb) * va = -(0.3kg/0.1kg) * 1.0m/s = -3.0m/s
